Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is running around in a supermarket, and the father needs to correct the behavior
Situation2: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Story: I gripped my phone tighter, trying to keep my voice steady as the customer on the other end raised his voice, demanding to know why our offer was worth his time. My script ran through my mind, but my eyes darted to my son, weaving between supermarket aisles, giggling as he knocked over a display of cereal boxes. I felt the heat rise in my cheeks—he knew better, and I was supposed to teach him right from wrong, to be respectful in public. But the customer’s tone sharpened, “Are you even listening? This sounds like a scam!” My manager’s words echoed in my head: never lose a customer, always stay calm, answer every question. But my son’s laughter turned to a shriek as he nearly collided with an elderly woman. I wanted to put the phone down, to kneel beside him and explain why his behavior wasn’t okay, to be the father he needed. But the customer was waiting, my job was on the line, and I was caught—torn between the demands of being a good father and a reliable employee, my heart pounding as I tried to decide which role to answer first.
